data.explanation: Probably a species of Mycena, the white gills, lack of nipple and brittle stipe give these away.
The dark brown cap color shows these have had wet conditions.
The nipple on these wet specimens is swollen, making them somewhat special.
Looks like a species of Panaeolus, lots of traits are off here (color, shape, nipple etc.). Notice where they are lying, a forrest floor, typically not the place to find libs.
A nice little catch, classically looking libs.
Probably a species of Mycena, notice the gills are white on these.
Beauties like these should not be left behind.
Panaeolus of some kind. These are too dark, almost black. The stipe especially should not be so dark.
These could be Galerina, Conocybe or Mycena, much too yellow and brittle.
Probably at least two species here, colors are way off on both cap and stipe. Probably Galerina/Conocybe/Mycena.
Maybe Panaeolus. The shape of the cap and lack of nipple give these away.
A nice catch of some classic libs. Don't leave such beauties standing.
Panaeolus species. Notice the stipe is too dark and the cap shape is too round, also no nipple on these.
The color of both the stipe and gills are off on all of them. Probably several species of Mycena/Galerina/Conocybe or similar.
Much too yellow/orange in color both on cap, gills and stipe. Also no nipple. Probably something like Conocybe/Galerina.
The milky white caps shows these have had dry conditions. Notice the distinct bell shape and nipples.
Clear nipples and bell shape, and the stripes on the edge of caps shows we are dealing with the right kind here.
Notice the swollen nipple and the stripes on the cap, this indicates wet conditions. The darker edge of the cap and the pale brown stipe are good signs.
These are lovely curled specimens, notice the nipples, the dark cap edge, and the white stipes with an almost purple/blueish glow. Looking magical indeed.
Stipe is light colored and fibrous. Cap is bell shaped, has a nipple and a darker edge.
The cap is unusually yellow, but cap shape and nipple is good, also a white curled stipe.
A nice cluster you should not leave behind.
This is very white in color, which makes it unusual. It has a nipple, bell shaped cap, white bended stipe. Albino lib.
These are just unusually large specimens, with unusually thick and short stipes. Notice the blueish color on the stipes.
Short stipes, possibly a little dried, not much nipple. None the less undoubtedly libs.
Clear nipple, strangely round cap shape, stipe seems to be stained by its own spores. Still it's a good one.
Unusually straight and dark stipe (possibly shaded), and the cap is very open. Otherwise it matches what we want, even has a clear nipple.
No nipples (very swollen due to wet conditions) but these are undoubtedly libs.
Protostropharia semiglobata is probably the species for these. They are very slimy.
Younger specimens but still libs.
A nice big one. Notice the unusually light cap color.
Classic Panaeolus. Notice the white on the edge of the caps, not something you see on libs.
Big specimens with open/broad cap.
This one seems to have a kind of growth failure on top, appearing like a huge nipple. Notice the non-fibrous stipe.
Group of big Panaeolus specimens.
Probably both Mycena and Panaeolus on this photo. Mycena have white gills and Panaeolus have no nipples and not a bell shaped cap.
Protostropharia semiglobata is probably the species for these. They are very slimy.
Small Panaeolus, and perhaps there are two species present on this photo.
Cluster of libs, some are older specimens, very open/broad caps.
Classic Panaeolus but these can cheat the untrained eye.
